No I'm not asking if it's for me. I know it's not. I don't need to put on first gen goggles to know that it's going to give me headaches and crap up my vision worse than it already is. Then there's the price. And lastly it's not something I'd be comfortable with my kids playing with when they get older. I guess my question more specifically is, are you guys hoping that the current generation that is interested in this with stay fans long enough to keep this alive?
Other than manufactured hype and shill pieces I really don't see a genuine interest in this.

Bias aside from any of our personal opinions but Forbes magazine and website has not been continuously linked with credibility. And while formerly being critical of Donald trump, now all of a sudden there has been a rapid fire of fluff pieces. Now I have a biased guess and you can come to your own conclusion but Forbes is likely still reeling from the pieces about their site which was mostly citizen journalists which was also likely a bid to keep them afloat. If they needed to keep afloat, a good idea would be to latch on to writing about trump which is what everyone else is doing. Only they have chosen in favor to save their failing business model.

It's probably one of the easier ones to get into and you might like it having not read others. The main story is good but it is filled with so much awful filler or side stories that will confuse people who read other comics. The entire story takes no chances and it ends up being very hollow. Marvel.com has the entire series is you wanna pay 10 bucks a month and the the game marvel ultimate alliance is all about the civil war and probably one of the best comic games there is.
Some better ones to get into first are avengers vs xmen or axis. Both have all the big names, great story, and do not require much background. Your local library might have a graphic novel section that contains it.

Or you know, no doom. What you described for doom could easily be its own movie. I mentioned before in a post that ff do not need their own movie to be introduced. I think just keep with the two that happened because frankly they were fine for their time. Bring reed from the campy version and recast everyone else and stick them in civil war. 15 minutes of screen time tops could totally justify why they are there and just have a couple of montages of reed building a prison to hold caps team if and when they are caught. Show sue getting pissed about and leaving. Have an epic fight scene with Johnny that ends in him getting badly injured and just show thing going to Europe. Then continue to include them in future movies and maybe when the dust has settled, give them their own movie. I think a great future collaboration would be with them and the inhumans or black panther because neither one appeals to a broad audience. So you take two things that have a small dedicated fan base and hope for the best.
I like doom but he is not necessary to the movie universe presently and requires far too much development. The sad truth is ff is not popular enough and most of the fans are too old to go see a reboot that is trying to appeal to a younger generation.

Marine, 10 years, you and your friends are saying it wrong. There is no hup. It's hump, hike or march. You're right that it's silly to argue about, but now you know what it's called. The only thing I can think you got it from is the Air Force and army often say hup instead of one while marching. As in, hup two three four. Edit: it's called humping because your gear makes a hump on your back when you're crouched over.

Algebra 2 is not a challenging class and it is not intended to be. I'd hold off on naming him a wunderkind just yet. Without proper studying techniques, as soon as he runs into a challenging class it could affect him greater than if he had been prepared. This is why you have able students dropping out after they get past their 2nd year of college and are not prepared for classes that you MUST study and research for. Rote formulae memorization only has an application in solving problems in high school and will serve you no purpose in life.

I did all my pre- engineering stuff at a community college. There was a scholarship program were engineering students could take two free courses a semester at the ridiculously expensive university nearby. Another great thing about community colleges is there is often guaranteed transfers to all universities in the same network. One more thing I would add is the exact same professors taught at the the more expensive universities, and there is literally no difference in courses.
